making meetings.


Call the meeting United Nations Assembly, Parliament
Congress. meeting, lodge garden club


For your meeting work effectively your chairman
reach decision.


You need rules hear all sides fairly yet
order and dispatch.


Each group make its rules the
Before it does anything else Congress adopts
sometimes after long, hard fight.


But candidate go your PTA and at
your elbow will stand almost forgotten general


People, meet General Robert:


In 1876 printed 1000 copies "Roberrs Rules Of
Order Since then have bought nearly 100000 copies
have changed rules order very little
other excellent books on the subject have


Rules of order back the early English Paraments indeed
to the Athenian Agora and the Roman Forum.

some rules of order. Most often the Generals.

VIEWS, PREvIEWs
AND REVIEWS


Edword Bonks

DISCUSSING ARIZONA LAW
Meet General Robert

NEW YORK (ANPD = The
election of ]. Raymond Jones as
the first Negro head of the Dem
ocratic New York County Com
mittee marked a milestone in
political history.


Leadership of Tammany Hall,
as the New York County Demo-
cratic organization is tradition
ally known, is a post with politi-
cal power and influence extending
far beyond this city's Borough of
Manhattan which comprises New
York County. AS head of the
number one party organization
in the New York City or down.
state area, which is the heart of
the statewide Democrat
strength in the state, the leader
of Tammany usually inherits the
party influence, and often the
title, of State Chairman. At the
national level, the New York State
chairman controls one of the two
largest state delegations at con-
ventionS.


John Raymond Jones was born
in St. Thomas, Virgin Islands,
IS years ago and moved to the
United States at the age of 10.
He worked at mental jobs and
advanced through political acti-
witty. His political wisdom earned
him the nickname of "The Fox"


Starting as deputy US. mar
shall, he held a number of non
elective political posts through
the years, progressing to secre-
tary to Justice of the Court of
General Sessions from which he
retired in 1859.

First Negroe Elected
To Head Dem. NY.


County Com mittee

Savory whiffs of glazed hams,
bronzed turkeys, spicy pies, and
fluffy rolls waited over the VAL
ley Friday. Eager diners threw
calorie charts away and caution
to the wind as they slipped hur-
riedly in their seats around the
steaming table. Tables creaked
with the load of succulent pud-
dings, salads, vegetables, and
meats.


Eaters attacked their plates
with zest and quickly the piles
of delicious foods decreas ed as
if by magic. Second helpings
we're offered without thought
of that all-important waistline.
Dieters gave their mistreated
stomachs a real holiday.


At this time of the year, the
makers of Unitrim, Regimen,
Wate-off, Lose-it, Tafon and Slim
can begin to take inventory or
90 on a vacation until December
26 rolls past.


Even Jack Spratt's wife eats
fattening goodies while Jack is
watching the scales.


am tempted to tamper with
those bathroom scales. Watch
the scales, girls--figures don't
lie. The figure in the dress may
tell you one half-truth, but the
figures on the scales tell the
awful truth. A few poonds a
day may be fun in the mouth,
but it's murder in the purse.


Reducing. aids are expensive.
Trim cigarettes cost twice as
much as the regular ones. Low
calorie dishes are SO costly that
the thought of the price should
do the trick. Bread for thinner
waistlines is sliced thin enough
to see through. Machines rangein
price from $40 to $500. The
cost of a new wardrobe amazes
you, especially after saying to
yourself or spouse for weeks
81 haven't a decent dress to
wear


In spite of all of these argu-
ments against eating and enjoy
ing the Christmas meal, sighted
turkey and sank same. After sew
eral visits to our friends homes,
needed help to walk. The best
sights and sounds passed over
and around the table.


Excuse me--where is that
bicarbonate of soda7 think my
husband just drank the last Aka
seltzer."

The leade Yshib role among Negroes IS no
different from that Of any other group. Hon.
ever, there has been a gradual change IN the
pattern of leade Yshib. The role has changed
from a one man leader, or a one man inter-
nlediary, to a broadening Of the role Of
le0de YShib.


1t is commonly believed that seUe7 raj per-
sons Witlin the Negro community haze the
magic formula for Wop1bing with the total
group. This belief is far from the truth,
be cause no fine or six persons can know the
thinking of the masses. Usually, the IN
telle ctuals, however, are useful in CON-
MUM eating with the majority group, since
they haze the facility NTH words. The genuine
leader must be able to express the desires
of the group.


The several seD-styled leaders, as well
as those 1OhO haze earned the rights of
leadership, are often jealous of the role
which one or tho might happen to play at
the time. These persons seem to be I'M
01UaYe of the fact that leadership is a many
sided thing, that leadership today might we'll
be fOllO1Oe YShib tomorrow In fact, the t1OO
roles are often complimentary.


The complaint is often made that Negroes
are not together Negro leaders are not
together. Why should these tVo segments
be together any more than the members
Of other groups !? There WtH be UaY1ed Uie1Os;
there Wiu be diUe Ys5ty Of opinions among
Negroes as weH as among others.


The Phoenix picture is similar to that
of other large cities. The era of one
leadership has been replaced by leadership
from several persons. The base of leadership
needs to be byoadened to include many more
persons pOho are qualified by experience
and education to fiji this role. Many more
Negroes should be limited to serve
boards, c0nqnaissio ions, and on other CON-
nast'aity bYoje cts.


Dr.. {. O. Greenfield


Guest Editor,
